try to resize an instance

The code above is only called from finish_migration in the libvirt virt driver.  What do you have set for use_cow_images in nova.conf?

What's the metadata on the image?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content:
the problem was that it was a AIO and I had to configure: 
allow_resize_to_same_host=True
scheduler_default_filters=AllHostsFilter
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~dron-3

comments.content:
Matt, I have testing environments which I install and re-install constantly and that specific one is no longer in existence :) 
However, the default installation is probably the one that I had so in use_cow_images in nova conf we use:
#images_type=default

Just so you know I did do further testing on this and configured AIO resize + tested with both qcow and raw images and with thin and raw images and  I found that we have a bug in icehouse 9probably with the scheduler) where sometimes we call migration (which fails the resize) and sometimes we do not (and resize succeeds). 

I think that this bug is actually related to libguestfs

comments.content:
I also meet the problem in my environment, I found that the owner of /var/lib/nova/instances/uuid/disk is root, instead of qemu.

So, I check the libervert configure file in /etc/libvirt/qume.conf:

# Some examples of valid values are:
#
#       user = "qemu"   # A user named "qemu"
#       user = "+0"     # Super user (uid=0)
#       user = "100"    # A user named "100" or a user with uid=100
#
user = "root"

# The group for QEMU processes run by the system instance. It can be
# specified in a similar way to user.
group = "root"

# Whether libvirt should dynamically change file ownership
# to match the configured user/group above. Defaults to 1.
# Set to 0 to disable file ownership changes.
dynamic_ownership = 0


It 's "root" instead of "qemu", change it to qemu and libvirtd server, The problem is salved.
